strings.string: In seconds - minimum 60 or zero (0) for unlimited idle time
Allow the IP of a user to fluctuate?
If this is enabled and a username and password are supplied in PHP_AUTH_USR and PHP_AUTH_PW, the system will try to authenticate a user with those credentials
Set this to 'No' to only allow users with accounts in the default matrix user system, rather than LDAP, IPB etc.
Use Default PHP session file save path

Using the default PHP session file may be required for system with multiple servers using shared file storage. However, enabling this option will prevent Site Network assets from operating correctly. This option should only be changed by advanced users: if you change this option all users who are currently logged in will be immediately logged out of their session.
The current session file save path is: %s
The maximum amount of system memory allocated to each instance of MySource Matrix web system.
The maximum amount of system memory allocated to each instance of the MySource Matrix cron system.

If this option is enabled and a username is found in the server variable specified below, the system will try to automatically log in a user with that username. (It will assume that the user has already been authenticated by some external mechanism.)

If this option is enabled, MySource Matrix will generate an HTTP Authentication dialog box instead of painting the applied login design. This will allow external tools to login to MySource Matrix by appending USE_HTTP_LOGIN=1 to the URL..
This setting limits the number of child assets displayed under an asset. You will be able to navigate between sets by using next and previous buttons.

Keywords available for use in the asset display name are %asset_assetid%, %asset_name% %asset_short_name% %asset_type_code% %asset_status% and %asset_num_kids%. Other characters may also be used for formatting, eg [%asset_assetid%] - %asset_short_name%
Current status for this asset can only be set from parent asset's details screen
Future status for this asset can only be set from parent asset's details screen
This asset cannot be made live because some mandatory %s fields are empty
This asset cannot be approved to go live because some mandatory %s fields are empty

Enforce the use of a certain type of character in passwords by specifying the minimum number of times it must be used.
Disallowing a character type will prevent users from including it in their passwords.
Cron Manager appears to be fine.
a future date and time. If no time is set, the new link will be created immediately else the cron manager will create the link at a future time
a future date and time. If no time is set, the selected link will be deleted immediately else the cron manager will delete the link at a future time
a future date and time. This feature is not availabe for the current asset
a future date and time. This feature is not availabe for the current asset

Paint layout to apply to the content

You can override the design this asset would inherit from its parent, with a design that is applied to this asset only. This override design does not affect the inheritance to this asset's children of any parent design.

Useful if you access MySource Matrix using a specific port number (i.e. specified in the URL). If you choose to ignore port numbers, URLs printed by MySource Matrix will not contain the port number by which the system is being accessed.
Rollback must be enabled and disabled using the Rollback Management Tool, or the "rollback_management.php" script in the MySource "scripts" directory
Show the differences between the system version and the edited version

Parent domains are examined when the system is setting the session cookie, and are useful if several system root URLs have a common parent domain (eg syd.example.com and melb.example.com). If the current URL ends with one of the parent domains then the cookie will be set on the parent domain instead, with the result that the user's session will persist across the parent domain and all its subdomains. Note that the common parent must be only one level up - alpha.syd.example.com and bravo.mel.example.com cannot share a cookie because their common parent domain is two levels up.

Static URLs can be used to offload delivery of static files and images to an alternative web server. This is an advanced configuration option and requires specific web server configuration to operate correctly.

Select a single fixed date and time using the boxes above.

Enter a period using the boxes above (eg. "3 days n the past"). The time period selected will be added or subtracted from the current date and time.

NOTE: To avoid confusion, a period of "0" (zero) means that the current time will be used.

Enter a period and time using the boxes above (eg. "3 days before today, at 09:00:00"). The period will be added or subtracted from the current date, and the specified time used.

NOTE: To avoid confusion, a period of "0" (zero) means the date used will be "today" at the time indicated.

If IP address is outside one of these ranges

The file uploaded should be a CSV file without a header row. Each line should contain exactly six fields: the first four being the octets of the network IP address, the fifth being the subnet mask (in CIDR format, eg. "255.255.255.0" would be represented in the file by "24"), and the sixth being a one (1) for a Grant rule or zero (0) for a Deny rule. The default Grant/Deny setting is not affected by any upload and should be set separately.
This condition matches using a regular expression. You can enter a simple string (eg. "MSIE") to match that in any part of the user agent. Or, you can use a more advanced pattern.
This condition matches using a regular expression. You can enter a simple string (eg. "MSIE") to match that in any part of the server variable chosen. Or, you can use a more advanced pattern.
In the IP address expression you can use an asterisk ("*") in place of a number to match all possible numbers within that octet.

A "hit" is an occasion when the condition is evaluated for a user.
A "session" is a calendar day on which there was at least one hit.
Whenever this condition returns true the counter is reset.

You can also upload a CSV file of remap URLs to add to the system. The format for each line must be:
"oldURL, newURL, expiry date (yyyy-mm-dd hh:mm:ss),never delete option (0 or 1)"
Example 2 (no expiry date and never delete(OFF))): http://www.mysite.com/page_1, http://www.mysite.com/home, , 0
Example 3 (no expiry date and never delete(ON)): http://www.mysite.com/page_1, http://www.mysite.com/home, , 1

If you choose to cascade the changes to permissions you make on "%1$s", the changes will also be made on all assets that fall under "%1$s" in the various hierarchies in which it exists. This will affect %2$s other assets.

Manually cascading permissions will try to set the current permissions of "%1$s" on all assets that fall under "%1$s" in the various hierarchies in which it exists. This will affect %2$s other assets.
Any additional permissions set on affected assets will not be removed during a manual cascade. Any permissions set on affected assets that conflict with ones set on "%1$s" will also not be changed.
NB. If you select to manually cascade, any permission changes you make will also cascade even if you do not select them to. Use the option on its own for more predictable results.

If you choose to cascade the role assignment changes you make for "%1$s", the changes will also be made on all assets that fall under "%1$s" in the various hierarchies in which it exists. This will affect %2$s other assets.

Request notes can be configured to make certain values in MySource Matrix (i.e. the name of the currently logged in user) available to Apache and/or its modules.

Example: Using the LogFormat directive, details of the currently logged in MySource Matrix user could be recorded in Apache the log.

LogFormat "%h %l %u %{sq-user-id}n - %{sq-user-name}n"

An SSL accelerator is a hardware or software proxy whose primary function is to handle the decoding of secure (HTTPS) requests. If MySource Matrix is located behind one of these, the SSL acclerator will handle the SSL layer of the request, and then send a plain (HTTP) request to the MySource Matrix system. This would normally mean that the system would use HTTP urls back, rather than the expected HTTPS. MySource Matrix is able to detect the presence of the SSL accelerator through the above settings, and send links using HTTPS protocol as expected.
The following settings will only apply if this setting is set to "Yes".

MySource Matrix can use two methods to determine whether a request has been made through an SSL accelerator: by matching the IP address of the proxy, or through a header injected by the proxy into the request made to the MySource Matrix system. Either or both match methods can be used. If "Both" is selected, the system is not considered behind an accelerator unless both methods match.

If IP address matching is turned on, MySource Matrix will only consider itself behind an SSL accelerator if the request (from the accelerator proxy) is made from the entered IP address. Remember that this the IP address that this system sees the accelerator as. This may be an internal network address, rather than any public-facing IP address.

When this is set to "Yes", and MySource Matrix detects that it is running behind an SSL accelerator, it will always produce secure (https://) URLs, except where an asset has been set to force standard http:// URLs.
This context has no conditions defined.
There are no alternate contexts defined. The default context will always be used, and context switching of content will not be available.
To create an alternate context, you must lock the screen first.

The default context will be used as a fallback when there is no current URL - for instance, as the initial context in a command-line script. It can also be explicitly selected as a User Group preference, or as a base context for a URL. You may change the default context's displayed name, but otherwise there are no conditions to configure, and its order cannot be edited.
Where context names appear italicised, no custom name has been set for that context, and the default name shown will be used. Edit the context to set a different name.
%1$s %2$s condition(s) must match before this alternate context can be considered for selection.

%1$s Add a new condition of type: %2$s
Only match the language if quality >= %s (must be between 0.0 and 1.0)

This condition will match if the language specified is found at any point in the "Accept-language" header in the request. If no Accept-language header is provided, the condition will fail.
If a quality value is set, the condition will only match if the request specifies a quality value of at least the set amount, or omits it entirely (which implies a quality of 1.0).
If a language is specified without a locale (eg. "English" instead of "English (Australia)"), the rule will match any entry in the header that includes that language, whether or not it is further qualified with a locale.
Match if the header named %1$s %2$s %3$s %4$s %5$s Case sensitive?

This condition will match if the header matches the condition specified. You can specify whether a header existed in the request or not, or matches a certain string.
If the match type is "does/does not exist", no value needs to be entered into the text box.
Match if the GET variable named %1$s %2$s %3$s %4$s %5$s Case sensitive?

This condition will match if the value of the entered GET variable matches the condition specified. You can specify whether a GET variable existed in the query string or not, or matches a certain string.
If the match type is "does/does not exist", no value needs to be entered into the text box.
Match if the POST variable named %1$s %2$s %3$s %4$s %5$s Case sensitive?

This condition will match if the value of the entered POST variable matches the condition specified. You can specify whether a POST variable existed in posted data or not, or matches a certain string.
If the match type is "does/does not exist", no value needs to be entered into the text box.

This condition will match if the URL used to access an asset matches (or does not match) the condition specified. Note that this is the URL used by MySource Matrix and will not include protocol, query strings or port numbers.
Match if the connection %1$s made on port: %2$s

This condition will match if the port used to access MySource Matrix matches (or does not match) the port specified. This is generally specified in the entered URL; where not specified, the default port for HTTP requests is 80; for HTTPS (secure) requests it is port 443.

This condition will match if a secure connection is (or is not) being used to access MySource Matrix.
Please note that this may be affected by proxies such as SSL accelerators, unless configured properly on the Proxy Configuration page. The system can only use what protocol is presented to it.

The Conditions for Context Detection column states the conditions that must be satisfied for a context to be selected through the context detection process. Context detection will occur on every request, unless a context has been forced through another method, either by user group preference or by global action. Alternate contexts are evaluated top to bottom, and the first one that matches is selected. If none match, the base context for the URL of the request is used, as set through the relevant Site asset (or the default context if no current URL exists, eg. in a CLI script).

Conditions do not affect a context's ability to be used through methods outside context detection, such as through global action, or User Group override. If you do not want a context to be selected through context detection, simply leave its conditions blank. The Valid ? column states whether a context's conditions are achievable, based on the number of valid conditions and the set logic (either "All" or "At least"). A context's conditions may be marked "not valid" if:

  • A context contains no valid conditions.
  • A context is set to require "at least" a certain number of matches, but does not have enough valid conditions to meet the requirement. (If some conditions are invalid, but not all, the conditions can still be "valid" if there enough valid ones.)
If enabled, errors will be sent to the *nix Syslog. Please contact your system administrator for appropriate settings if you are to use this feature.

Syslog defines a number of "facilities", which can be used to perform different actions on different types of messages. You can send syslog messages to the default "user" facility, or one of eight user-defined "local" facilities. Changing this may be useful if you are planning to send all MySource Matrix system messages into a separate syslog facility.
If entered, this string will be used to identify the system within the syslog. If not entered, the long name of the system ("%s") will be used.

A request for an access token failed. URL: %1$s, HTTP Code: %2$s, Error: %3$s

This screen shows which assets have this schema either applied or denied.

Where the applying or denying of the schema is cascaded unaffected through a tree of assets, only the top asset of that tree will be displayed. However, if any children underneath the asset do anything different to its parent - such as denying the schema where its parent had applied (or vice-versa), or it no longer cascades to new assets - a child entry in the table is created.
This schema is not applied to any assets.
This design is not applied to any assets.
The install key is automatically generated when the step_03.php script is run to reconfigure your system - it cannot be changed here.
